sense.name: Cut at (as if) with a hacking tool (into pieces).
sense.commentary: INCLUDES: CHOP UP, CHOP AWAY, CHOP AWAY AT, CHOP THROUGH NOTE: Includes metaphorical uses.
sense.examples: He chopped the wood into logs for the fire. John chopped up his dissertation. The chef chopped the meat into small cubes for the stew. Bush vows to chop away at logging legislation. The killer chopped at his body with a hatchet. Our boat chopped through the swells at top speed.

sense.name: CHOP DOWN: Cut down.
sense.examples: George chopped down the cherry tree. Land owners began to chop down large acreages of forest.

sense.name: CHOP OFF: Remove by or as if by cutting.
sense.examples: Van Gogh chopped off his own ear. The gardener chopped off the dead branch.

sense.name: Strike or hit sharply, perhaps as in sport.
sense.examples: He chopped his opponent ruthlessly. When the player chopped his opponent, the team received a five yard penalty.

sense.name: Form or shape by chopping.
sense.commentary: NOTE: For this sense, the action must produce a resultant shape or form.
sense.examples: The children chopped a hole in the backyard. The bullet chopped a large hold in his skull.

sense.name: Move suddenly.
sense.examples: His hand chopped quickly to the right, completing the card trick.
